message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The behavior described by the mother is age-appropriate and normal for a 3-year-old child adjusting to a new routine. Autism spectrum disorder and conduct disorder typically present with more severe and persistent behavioral patterns. Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder is characterized by severe and frequent temper outbursts, which is not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. It is important to note that the child's behaviors are occurring in specific situations (getting dressed/dropped off, mealtime/bedtime) and that he is well-behaved during the day at daycare. Additionally, his behavior is consistent with typical development for a 3-year-old experiencing some separation anxiety in response to his mother returning to work. Therefore, the most likely cause of his behavior is normal development. The other options, such as autism spectrum disorder, conduct disorder, and disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, would have different symptoms and would not be consistent with the child's behavior as described.

The boy’s behavior is within the normal range for a 3-year-old who has just experienced a major change in routine (mother returning to work, being dropped off at daycare). Tantrums are common in this age group and are often a way for children to express frustration or feeling overwhelmed. There is no indication of any other behavioral or developmental issues, making normal development the most likely cause of the behavior.

While it is always important to monitor a child's behavior and seek medical advice if concerned, at this point it seems unlikely that the boy has a behavioral disorder such as autism spectrum disorder or conduct disorder.
